Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2012 05:00PM lovetorun wrote: I had almost this same question as you when I came to this.  I was dx with IDC almost 1 year ago.  I was 43 at the time and no history in my family and was in the best shape of my life training for a marathon.  We were planning on taking out 1 tumor and a sentinal node bx.  It turned out we took out 2 seperate tumors.  one of them was 1.7cm and the other 1.4cm.  I also had 1of 2 positive nodes, and positive margins.  I too was dx earlier as angiolymphatic.  They wanted to take the rest of my nodes and I dug my feet into the ground on that one.  We did a re-do lumpectomy with the idea if that was successful we would move on with treatment.  It was successful.  My oncotype was on the low end but the higher of the low end with a 15.  I also have a mystery lesion in my sternum that bone scans, biopsy's, and a PET scan finally ruled out cancer but still not really certain.  I chose to do chemo for a few reasons.  Angiolymphatic, 1 pos node, my age, my children, and the unknown that something may be floating around in me.  I am naturally a worrier and felt I may worry for the rest of my life that something could be worse.  I would rather feel crappy and lose my hair while I am young enough to bounce back and feel like I did everything possible. I also just completed 6 weeks of radiation and have started on Tamox for the next 5 years.  It is worth the loss of hair, feeling yucky, to know I did everything available to me to be safe.  I am now training for that marathon that got taken away from me last year and I feel incredible!  My last chemo was 11/2/11 and though I have a few slight side effects from it, I am strong and on my way to living again!  You should do what feels best to you in your heart.  Numbers are important but it is what those numbers mean to you that should help you make your decisions.  Chemo is bad, and maybe I was lucky, but it wasnt as bad as I thought it would be, and I would do it all over again the exact same way.  I wish you peace in your decision making and a journey back to health that is speedy and smooth.
